title: Aidan’s E-Portfolio
text: Hi, I’m Aidan. Born and raised in Toronto, Ontario, I completed my Bachelor of Science in Biodiversity and Conservation Biology at the University of Toronto in 2023 with minors in GIS and philosophy. I then moved to Vancouver, BC, to expand my knowledge and skills in geomatics and remote sensing in the Master of Geomatics for Environmental Management program at the University of British Columbia. My focus during this graduate degree has been applications of remotely sensed data for animal conservation on campus.

text: GIS Resume 2023  by  rankina001

text:

Despite listing them on your resume, it may also be pertinent to create a seperate tab for publications and reports. As your career progresses, this list may become quite long, so be sure to organize things. You may want to point to ‘most recent’ publications, or categorize things by project/topic.

title: Content & Deliverables

Project Deliverable 1
This is a sample page where you can archive project deliverables.

title: Content and deliverables
text:
The MGEM program covered a wide breadth of topics related to GIS, remote sensing, ecology, and environmental management challenges. Below are some deliverables from many of the courses.




Mapping the impact of hydroelectric dams on salmon habitat access on Vancouver Island.
 Mapping least cost paths for Grizzly bear management in an Alberta conservation unit.





Code snippet of a function to calculate reflectance in Landsat bandwidths from raw reflectance values.
landsat_band <- function(df, lwr, upr, centre) { ##function to calculate each landsat band value
  df[df$wavelength>=lwr&df$wavelength<=upr,] %>% ##selects values between given lower and upper wavelengths
    mutate(mixel_1 = mean(mixel_1), ##converts each pixel value to the mean of the chosen wavelengths
           mixel_2 = mean(mixel_2),
           mixel_3 = mean(mixel_3),
           mixel_4 = mean(mixel_4),
           mixel_5 = mean(mixel_5),
           wavelength = centre) %>% ##converts wavelength value to the value of the centre of the band
    slice(1) ##removes extraneous identical rows
}

landsat_b1 <- landsat_band(spectra_mixed_wide, 450, 520, 485) ##apply function for each band
landsat_b2 <- landsat_band(spectra_mixed_wide, 520, 600, 560)
landsat_b3 <- landsat_band(spectra_mixed_wide, 630, 690, 660)
landsat_b4 <- landsat_band(spectra_mixed_wide, 770, 900, 835) 
landsat_b5 <- landsat_band(spectra_mixed_wide, 1550, 1750, 1650)
landsat_b7 <- landsat_band(spectra_mixed_wide, 2090, 2350, 2220)



A proposed project connecting landscape ecology concepts like ecological connectivity, landscape fragmentation, and species dispersal, with remote sensing techniques and data sources.
    Landscape Ecology project proposal  by  rankina001

title: Content & Deliverables
text:
Arcpy cursor snippet used to generate building capacity numbers based on building code limits to estimate human presence numbers on campus.
##checks if there is already a field for building capacity created
if "capacity" not in [f.name for f in arcpy.ListFields("buildings_clipped")]:
  
    ##creates new field in attribute table
    arcpy.management.AddField(in_table="buildings_clipped",
                              field_name="capacity", 
                              field_type="FLOAT")

##creating update cursor for buildings_clipped feature, looking at four specific fields
with arcpy.da.UpdateCursor("buildings_clipped", field_names=["Shape_Area", "bldg_usage", "max_floors", "capacity"]) as cursor:
  
    ##for every row, if the row has a building area value, then the building max capacity is added to the new field
    for row in cursor:
      
        if row[0] is not None:
            ##max capacity is building area * number of floors * 0.4 people per m^2
            row[3] = row[0] * row[2] * 0.4 
        else:
            pass

        cursor.updateRow(row)

title: Content & Deliverables
text:
You can also provide a frame linking to external websites. For example, here is a link to a Google Earth Engine application I developed. The full-screen GEE application is available here in case you’re interested.
(To use the GEE tool, navigate to any city you’d like, hit apply filters, and click anywhere on the map to retrieve a time-series of Landsat surface temperature observations for that point. Areas where the maximum temp exceeded 35 degrees Celsius in your date-range are highlighted in red.)

title: Content & Deliverables
section: Urban ecology: Stream temperature as a function of impermeable land cover
text:
Urban ecology: Stream temperature as a function of impermeable land cover
Increased impermeable surface cover increases runoff and temperatures in urban streams with ecological implications. Analysis of impermeable surface area at sites in Toronto region watersheds was carried out to test the relevance of this relationship. Surface impermeability is correlated with mean stream temperature at large scales, but minimum and maximum temperatures display no relationship. This may be due to the homogeneous urban landscape, the impact of cool water entering upstream at headwaters, or other physical characteristics of urban streams.

                              field_name="capacity",

##creating update cursor for buildings_clipped feature, looking at four specific fields
with arcpy.da.UpdateCursor("buildings_clipped", field_names=["Shape_Area", "bldg_usage", "max_floors", "capacity"]) as cursor:

title: Capstone project
text:
Capstone project for the MGEM program. This project involved classifying land cover at the University of British Columbia Vancouver campus and then modelling animal and human movement across the landscape to identify points of potential conflict and potential corridors to promote coexistence.



Land cover on campus was classified using random forests in Python, from Planet SkySat satellite imagery and Vancouver public LiDAR.

The most important features in training the random forests classifier were the normalized difference vegetation index, a measure of vegetation derived from the red and near-infrared bands of the imagery, and the digital surface model, an elevation model of surface features derived from LiDAR.




From the classified land cover map, human pedestrian and wildlife connectivity models were run and typical connectivity maps were created. Above is the mean connectivity values per 0.5x0.5 metre cell, calculated from combining connectivity model outputs for five different test species. Species resistance values per land cover class were reclassified according to the table below, where each value represents the relative resistance or difficulty each species has in moving through a cell of the associated land cover type.

Configuration file for running Omniscape connectivity model in Julia, with coyote species-specific parameters.
resistance_file = C:/Users/ranki/Documents/Grad/FCOR599/campus_resample_v2.tif
radius = 100
block_size = 21
project_name = C:/Users/ranki/Documents/Grad/FCOR599/coyote_config/coyote_test

source_from_resistance = true
r_cutoff = 30
reclassify_resistance = true
reclass_table = C:/Users/ranki/Documents/Grad/FCOR599/coyote_config/coyote_reclass_table.txt
calc_normalized_current = true

precision = single
solver = cholmod

title: Other work
text:
Increased impermeable surface cover increases runoff and temperatures in urban streams with ecological implications. Analysis of impermeable surface area at sites in Toronto region watersheds was carried out to test the relevance of this relationship. Surface impermeability is correlated with mean stream temperature at large scales, but minimum and maximum temperatures display no relationship. This may be due to the homogeneous urban landscape, the impact of cool water entering upstream at headwaters, or other physical characteristics of urban streams.




Data was accessed from open-source repositories maintained by the Toronto Region Conservation Authority and the Province of Ontario Geohub.

title: Other work
text:
Lost Rivers of Toronto
A project mapping historical lost and buried rivers in Toronto. Contributed digitized rivers from early 20th century historical maps and edited existing layers based on potential stream locations from elevation.

title: Content and deliverables
text:
Code snippet of a function to calculate reflectance in Landsat bandwidths from raw reflectance values.
landsat_band <- function(df, lwr, upr, centre) { ##function to calculate each landsat band value
  df[df$wavelength>=lwr&df$wavelength<=upr,] %>% ##selects values between given lower and upper wavelengths
    mutate(mixel_1 = mean(mixel_1), ##converts each pixel value to the mean of the chosen wavelengths
           mixel_2 = mean(mixel_2),
           mixel_3 = mean(mixel_3),
           mixel_4 = mean(mixel_4),
           mixel_5 = mean(mixel_5),
           wavelength = centre) %>% ##converts wavelength value to the value of the centre of the band
    slice(1) ##removes extraneous identical rows
}

landsat_b1 <- landsat_band(spectra_mixed_wide, 450, 520, 485) ##apply function for each band
landsat_b2 <- landsat_band(spectra_mixed_wide, 520, 600, 560)
landsat_b3 <- landsat_band(spectra_mixed_wide, 630, 690, 660)
landsat_b4 <- landsat_band(spectra_mixed_wide, 770, 900, 835) 
landsat_b5 <- landsat_band(spectra_mixed_wide, 1550, 1750, 1650)
landsat_b7 <- landsat_band(spectra_mixed_wide, 2090, 2350, 2220)
